flds.name: Hide others on the back side

note_models.name: Cloze (Hide all)

tmpls.afmt:
<script>
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
setTimeout(function() {
    var clozeBoxes = document.querySelector(".cloze cloze2_w");
    var elements = document.querySelectorAll("cloze2." + clozeBoxes.className);
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.add("cloze");
        elements[i].style.display="inline";
    }
}, 0);
/* --- DO NOT DELETE OR EDIT THIS SCRIPT --- */
</script>



{{cloze:Text}}
{{#Extra}}
<hr>
{{Extra}}
{{/Extra}}

{{#Hide others on the back side}}
<style>
cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

cloze2_w {
    display: inline-block;
    width: 5em;
    height: 1em;
    background-color: #ffeba2;
}

.cloze cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

.cloze cloze2_w {
    display: none;
}

cloze2.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: inline;
}

cloze2_w.reveal-cloze2 {
    display: none;
}

.cloze2-toggle {
    -webkit-appearance: none;
    display: block;
    font-size: 1.3em;
    height: 2em;
    background-color: #ffffff;
    width: 100%;
    margin-top: 20px;
}

.cloze2-toggle:active {
    background-color: #ffffaa;
}
</style>

<script>
function toggle() {
var elements = document.querySelectorAll('cloze2, cloze2_w');
    for(var i = 0 ; i < elements.length ; i++) {
        elements[i].classList.toggle('reveal-cloze2');
    }
}
</script>

<button class='cloze2-toggle' onclick='toggle()'>Toogle mask</button>
{{/Hide others on the back side}}

fields:
Fluid in the body

==={{c1::cell membrane::structure separating the two}}===
{{c3::Extracellular}} fluid (17L)

Cell membrane

Separates 
{{c4::intracellular}} fluid <-> {{c5::extracellular}} fluid
Regulate {{c1::tranasport}} of matter
maintain {{c2::volume}} and {{c3::composition}} of fluids

Normal ionic concentration


Extracellular

Maintained by: 
{{c4::Na-K pump}}
3 {{c5::Na+}} out for 2 {{c6::K-}} in
Membrane {{c7::im::Yes/no}}permeable to the ions

Blood plasma

Total blood volume: ~{{c1::5.5}} L
~{{c2::20}}% (~{{c2::3}} L) in circulation (heart+blood vessels)
{{c3::3}} L being plasma volume
Balance: {{c4::cellular}} element
{{c5::RBC}}, {{c6::WBC}}, {{c7::Platlets}}
~{{c8::2.5}} L

{{c2::75}}% (~{{c3::13}} L) of total ECF
Found outside the {{c6::intracvascular}} compnent
Separated by: {{c5::capillary wall}}
Water and solutes crosses 
{{c7::Capillary wall::structure}}: interstitium - blood plasma
{{c8::cell membrane::structure}}: interstitium - cytoplasm

{{c1::!Transcellular}} fluid

Fluid trapped in spaces surrounded by {{c2::!epithelial}} cells
~{{c3::5}}% (~{{c4::1}} L) of ECF
E.g.
{{c5::Synovial::related to joints}} fluid
{{c6::cerebrospinal::related to brain and spinal cord}} fluid

Note: Does not include fluids that are {{c7::outside of body}} (e.g. GI tract, urinary bladder)

Membrane transport

{{c4::!Simple Diffusion}}

Substances: {{c3::uncharged::property}}
flux {{c1::directly::dircetly/inversely}} proportional to concentration difference
Driven by: {{c2::!thermal}} motion of the molecules.

Membrane transport

{{c2::!Osmosis}}

Movement of {{c3::!water}}
through {{c4::!semi::yes/no}}permeable membrane
Higher water concentration {{c1::->::direction}} lower water concentration

"{{c4::!Semipermeable}}" as in: 
Permeable to water: {{c5::yes}}
Permeable to solute: {{c6::no}}

{{c1::Aquaporin}}

Main route of water movment in and out of cell:

{{c2::Widely::extent}} distributed throughout the body

Membrane transport

Mechanisms

{{c3::!Pores}}:
Default state: {{c1::!Always open}}
Conformational change: {{c2::No::yes/no}}

Membrane transport

Mechanisms

{{c2::!Channels}}
Membrane protein that {{c1::!can be opened and closed::property}}
Conformational change: {{c3::Yes}}
Open to intracellular and extracellular solutions {{c4::simultaneously::manner}}

Membrane transport

Mechanisms

{{c2::!Carriers}}
Membrane protein that {{c1::!can be opened and closed::property}}
Has {{c5::!at least 2::#}} gate/s
Conformational change: {{c3::Yes}}
Ca<sub>2+ </sub>pumps are found in the {{c1::plasma mebrane:plamsa membrane or cytosol}} of most cells and are called {{c1::PMCA}} (plamsa membrane Ca2+ ATPase).
Ca2+ pumps exchange {{c1::one::how many}} H+ for {{c2::one::how many}} ca2+ for each molecule of ATP that is hydrolyzed.
In a Ca2+ pump, such as a plasma membrane Ca-H pump or the Na-Ca exchanger, the calcium ion is pumped {{c1::out of::into or out of}} the cell.

{{c2::SERCAs::what is the transporter called}} ( sarcoplasmic and endoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase) transport two H+ out and two Ca2+ ions inside an intracellular organelle like the {{c1::sarcoplasmic reticulumn}} in muscle cells,  for each molecule of ATP hydrolyzed out.

{{c1::Vacuolar-type}} pumps H+ from the cytoplasm to the {{c2::interior of an organelle}}. The interior of the organelle becomes more {{c2::acidic}}.The low pH genergated inside these lysosomes, endosomes, secretory vesicles, storage vesicles, and the golgi apparatus are important for their function.
The multidrug resistant tranporters (MDR1) are also called {{c1::P-glycoprotein}}.

MDR1 (P-glycoprotein) extrudes {{c1::carionic metabolites}} and {{c1::drugs}} across the cell membrane. These transporters are expressed by a wide variety of cells including {{c1::liver}} cells, {{c1::kidney}} cells, and {{c1::GI tract}} cells.
Cancer cells upregulate {{c1::MDR1}} transporters to pump anticancer drugs out of the cell.

In {{c1::secondary active transport::type of tranport}} molecules are tranpsorted against their concentration gradient by using the energy in the electrochemical gradient of other molecules to drive this tranport. {{c1::ATP}} is not used.
The two major classes of secondary active transporters are: {{c1::cotransporters/symporters}} and {{c1::exchangers/antiporters}}

{{c2::Cotranporters/Symporters}} are intrisnisc membrane proteins that move the "driving" solute and "driven" solute {{c1::in the same direction::same or opposite direction}}. Usually, this is driven by energy provided from teh inwardly directed {{c1::Na+}} gradient.
Common examples of Cotransporters/Symporters are: {{c1::SGLT (sodium-glucose linked tranporter)}} and {{c2::Sodium Amino acid transporter}}

{{c2::Exchangers/Antiporters}} are intrinsic membrane proteins that move the "driving" solute and the "driven" solute in {{c1::opposite::same or opposite}} directions.  Generally cations are exchanged for {{c1::cations}} and anion are exchanged for {{c1::anion.}}
An example of an antiporter/exchanger is the {{c1::sodium-calcium exchanger}}

The Na-Ca exchanger mediates the exchange of {{c1::3::how many}}Na+ ions per {{c1::1::how many }}Ca2+ ion. Na-Ca exchangers are {{c2::electrogenic}} because they move a net positive charge inside the cell.
The main way that water passes through a membrane is through proteins called {{c1::aquaporins}}.
True or False: Transport of water across biological membranes requires certain pumps on occasion.
False; transport of water across biological membranes is always passive, no pumps described.
What is osmolality?
A measure of the number of osmotically active solutes in a single solution.
Membranes with low fluidity (those whose phospholipids have long saturated fatty acid chians with few double bonds) exhibit {{c1::lower::lower/higher}} H<sub>2</sub>O permeability.
To a certain extent, single water molecules can dissolve in lipid bilayers and thus move across cell membranes at a low but finite rate by {{c2::simple diffusion.::what process?}}
What component in membranes decreases fluidity and may further reduce H<sub>2</sub>O permeability?
Cholesterol
Normal plasma osmolality is {{c1::290}} mOsm.
Solutions having an osmolality of 290 mOsm are described as {{c1::isosmolal::isosmolal/hyperosmolal/hypoosmolal}}
Solutions having an osmolality above 290 mOsm are described as {{c1::hyperosmolal::isosmolal/hyperosmolal/hypoosmolal}}
Solutions having an osmolality below 290 mOsm are described as {{c1::hypoosmolal::isosmolal/hyperosmolal/hypoosmolal}}
The asymmetric distribution of impermeant proteins in plasma versus interstitial fluid creates an osmotic force called {{c1::protein osmotic pressure}}, colloid osmotic pressure or oncotic pressure.
The oncotic pressure difference tends to pull water from the {{c1::intersitium}} to the {{c2::plasma}}
The oncotic pressure difference is opposed by the {{c1::hydrostatic pressure::what kind of pressure?}} difference across the capillary wall which drives fluid from plasma into the interstitum.
7651635408a04e5dba79f7cc9c4a3eeb-ao-1
7651635408a04e5dba79f7cc9c4a3eeb-ao-2
Water is at {{c1::equilibrium}} across the wall of a capillary when the colloid osmotic and hydrostastic pressure differences are equal.
When the hydrostatic pressure exceeds the colloid osmotic pressure, the resulting movement of water out of the capillary is called {{c1::ultrafiltration}}.
6b785dfc6c0c4eb5bd939507abfdd19a-ao-1
6b785dfc6c0c4eb5bd939507abfdd19a-ao-2
6b785dfc6c0c4eb5bd939507abfdd19a-ao-3
What happens to a cell placed in a hypertonic solution?

The cell shrinks; 

a hypertonic solution has increased solute, and a net movement of water outside causing the cell to shrink.
What happens to a cell placed in a hypotonic solution?

The cell swells;

A hypotonic solution has decreased solute concentration, and a net movement of water inside the cell, causing swelling or breakage.
Movement of water in and out of cells is driven by {{c1::osmotic gradients}} only.
What happens to a cell placed in Isotonic solution?
There is a balance of water concentration (cell unchanged).
What is osmosis?
Osmosis is the movement of water or other solvent through a plasma membrane from a region of low solute concentration to a region of high solute concentration.
Sodium Potassium Pumps are moving with or against the gradient (In terms of Sodium)
Against the gradient.
Sodium Potassium Pumps are moving with or against the gradient (In terms of Potassium)
Against the gradient.
Sodium Potassium pumps push Sodium inside or outside of the cell?
Outside of the cell.
Sodium Potassium pumps push potassium inside or outside of the cell?
Inside of the cell.
What is the energy source and products of the Na/K pump?
ATP is used and changed to ADP + P<sub>i</sub>
What are the two conformational states of the Na/K pump and what are they called?

E1 is when the Na binding sites are open to the inside of the cell. 
E2 is when the Na Binding sites are open to the extracellular space.
What is it called when the net extrusion of a process is positive?
Electrogenic.
Prior to Stage 1 in the Modes of actions of the Na/K pump, K is released inside of the cell. What happens in Stage 1-8 until K is again released in the Intramembrane space?.

Stage 1. ATP is bound to the to the Na/K pump.
Stage 2. Na+ is bound to the pump.
Stage 3. ATP phosphorylates the pump to change the confirmation to allow open the pump into it's E2 confirmation.
Stage 4. Na+ binding affinity is dropped and the Na+ leaves the pump.
Stage 5. Minor confirmation change allows K- to bind to the pump. 
Stage 6. 2 K- Binds to the pump. 
Stage 7. Inorganic Phophoate (inside of the cell is hydrolyzed, changing the confirmation of the pump to close off the extracellular entrance.
Stage 8. ATP is bound and releases K+ into the intracellular space.
What does Ouabain do to a Na/K Pump?
Changes the confirmation and prevents K from binding.
What voltage is the typical cell kept at thanks to the Na/K pump?
60 mV
